content: The Act is titled the "District of Columbia College Access Improvement Act of 2002" and includes a public school program. Section 3(c)(2) of the District of Columbia College Access Act of 1999 is amended to include residency requirements for individuals starting undergraduate studies within 3 years of high school graduation. The District of Columbia College Access Improvement Act of 2002 amended residency requirements for individuals starting undergraduate studies within 3 years of high school graduation. Domicile in DC for specific periods is now necessary for eligibility at eligible institutions. The District of Columbia College Access Improvement Act of 2002 amended residency requirements for individuals starting undergraduate studies within 3 years of high school graduation, ensuring eligibility at eligible institutions based on specific criteria. The District of Columbia College Access Improvement Act of 2002 amended residency requirements for individuals starting undergraduate studies within 3 years of high school graduation, ensuring eligibility at eligible institutions based on specific criteria, including requirements described in section 484(a)(5) of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The District of Columbia College Access Improvement Act of 2002 amended residency requirements for individuals starting undergraduate studies within 3 years of high school graduation. Section 5(c)(1)(B) of the Act was amended to remove the requirement that the main campus of a private school be located in Maryland or Virginia. Section 6 of the District of Columbia College Access Act of 1999 is amended to limit the Mayor's use of federal funds for administrative expenses to 7%. Administrative expenses are defined as those not directly related to tuition and fees for eligible students. Subsections (e) and (f) are redesignated as subsections (f) and (g), with a new subsection added after subsection (d). The District of Columbia government is directed to establish a dedicated account for programs under sections 3 and 5, which includes Federal funds, local funds, unobligated balances from previous fiscal years, and interest earned on balances. The dedicated account established for programs under sections 3 and 5 shall only use funds for carrying out the specified programs and interest earned on balances. SEC. 7. LIMIT ON AGGREGATE AMOUNT OF FEDERAL FUNDS FOR PUBLIC SCHOOL AND PRIVATE SCHOOL PROGRAMS. The District of Columbia is authorized to appropriate up to $17,000,000 for programs in fiscal years 2003, 2004, and 2005. Amendments are made to public and private school programs regarding funding limits.
